plausible_answers.text: the essential nature of secondary qualities

qas.question: What did Newton reject that Descartes did not?

plausible_answers.text: extension, hardness, impenetrability, mobility, and inertia

qas.question: What did Descartes say were the universal qualities of matter?
Both primary and secondary properties are suited to what form of description?

context: Isaac Newton (<b0_0>1643<b0_0/>–1727) inherited Descartes' mechanical conception of matter. In the third of his "<b1_0>Rules of Reasoning in Philosophy<b1_0/>", Newton lists the universal qualities of matter as "<b3_0>extension, hardness, impenetrability, mobility, and inertia<b3_0/>". Similarly in Optics he conjectures that God created matter as "solid, massy, hard, impenetrable, movable particles", which were "...even so very hard as never to wear or break in pieces". The "primary" properties of matter were amenable to <b4_0>mathematical<b4_0/> description, unlike "secondary" qualities such as color or taste. Like Descartes, Newton rejected <b2_0>the essential nature of secondary qualities<b2_0/>.
